{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} In the United Kingdom, [[Association football|football]] clubs sometimes choose to enter [[Administration (law)|administration]] when they are unable to pay off outstanding [[debt]]s. Under the [[Insolvency Act 1986]], a business will face a winding-up order bringing them to court and if it is shown that a business cannot pay debts as they fall due or cannot repay outstanding debts then the company will be classified as [[UK insolvency law#Definition|insolvent]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1986/45/section/123|title=Insolvency Act 1986 (c. 45) – Part IV Winding Up of Companies Registered under the Companies Acts – Chapter VI Winding Up by the Court – Grounds and effect of winding-up petition|work=[[UK Statute Law Database]]|publisher=[[Office of Public Sector Information]]|accessdate=13 October 2013}} '''Administration''' puts accountants "in charge of pretty much everything apart from coaching the players and picking the team". For a football club in administration, the "football creditors rule" requires football-related debts such as wages owed to players and staff, and transfer fees owed to other clubs to be paid first.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7741859.stm|title=Football clubs owe tax millions |last=Grant|first=Paul|date=23 November 2008|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 February 2010}} ==England and Wales== In 2000, [[ITV Digital]] bought the broadcasting rights to [[The Football League|Football League]] and [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] matches in a three-year, £315m deal.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-110973/Fears-soccer-clubs-ITV-Digital-sale.html|title=Fears for soccer clubs as ITV Digital is put up for sale|work=[[The Daily Mail]]|accessdate=14 March 2010|location=London}} In March 2002, the company went bankrupt owing the League £180 million which it said it "cannot afford to pay".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/1896732.stm|title=ITV Digital goes broke|date=27 March 2002|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=14 March 2010}} As a result of this many Football League clubs had financial problems and entered administration.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/1898021.stm|title=ITV Digital woes bring football crisis|date=28 March 2002|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=14 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/oct/22/newsstory.sport|title= Crisis clubs|date=22 October 2002|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=13 October 2013 | location=London}} Before the implementation of a points deduction it was perceived that clubs had "manipulated and abused [administration] as a way of shedding debts then restructuring, and borrowing again once the hapless creditors had been fobbed off with their 8p in the pound".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7305998.stm|title= Football administration|last=Farquhar|first=Gordon|date=20 March 2008|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 February 2010}} In September 2003, it was proposed that clubs entering administration would be docked 10 points. A [[Fit and proper person test|'fit and proper persons' test]] was also introduced in an attempt to prevent fraudulent activities. If a person was previously director at a club which was in "administration twice during a five-year period" or at "two different clubs that have each gone into administration in a five-year period" then they would be prevented from becoming the controlling shareholder of a [[Football League]] club.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/5030910.stm|title= The murky world of football finances|last=Summers|first=Chris|date=28 June 2006|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=13 March 2010}} A 'fit and proper persons' test was also introduced for directors of [[Premier League]] clubs.{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/staticFiles/12/66/0,,12306~91666,00.pdf#page=17 |title=The F.A. Premier League: Charter Report 2004/05 |publisher=[[Premier League]] |accessdate=13 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818150113/http://www.premierleague.com/staticFiles/12/66/0%2C%2C12306~91666%2C00.pdf |archivedate=18 August 2011 }} In November 2009, [[Stephen Vaughan, Sr.]] became the first director to fail the 'fit and proper persons' test.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/nov/18/chester-city-fit-proper-person-test|title=Chester City chief becomes first owner to fail fit and proper person test|last= Conn|first=David|date=18 November 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=13 October 2013 | location=London}} To ease financial problems for clubs that had been relegated, "parachute payments" were introduced to give time to adapt to the financial gulf between divisions.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/points-threat-to-clubs-choosing-administration-580968.html|title=Points threat to clubs choosing administration|last=Warshaw|first=Andrew|date=24 September 2003|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=26 February 2010 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100409015315/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/points-threat-to-clubs-choosing-administration-580968.html| archivedate= 9 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} The deductions of 10 points in the [[Football League]] and 9 points in the [[Premier League]] were ratified in 2004, with the rule in place from the start of the 2004–05 season.{{cite web|url=http://breaking.tcm.ie/archives/2004/0115/sport/chairmen-to-agree-points-deductions-129765.html|title=Chairmen to agree points deductions|date=15 January 2004|work=[[BreakingNews.ie]]|publisher=[[Thomas Crosbie Holdings]]|accessdate=26 February 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2004/jan/30/newsstory.sport14|title=Crisis clubs will lose nine points|last=Chaudhary|first=Vivek|date=20 January 2004|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=13 October 2013 | location=London}} The League also adopted rules that prevented any side from being in administration for either two successive seasons or eighteen consecutive months. The reason for the deduction being a point less in the Premier League was that the teams play eight fewer fixtures than Football League clubs. The first club to incur this new penalty were [[League One]] side [[Wrexham F.C.]] who entered administration on 3 December 2004.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4064257.stm|title= Wrexham FC in administration|date=3 December 2004|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=26 February 2010}} [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] filed for administration with only a few days remaining in the [[2006–07 Football League Championship|2006–07 season]], which automatically triggered a 10-point penalty. This placed Leeds at the bottom of the table and relegated the club, but they were extremely likely to have been relegated anyway. By entering administration during the 2006–07 season, they hoped to avoid starting the [[2007–08 Football League#League One|2007–08 season]] on −10 points. The following week, [[Boston United F.C.|Boston United]] entered administration in the final minutes of a defeat to [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]] which ensured they were relegated to the [[Football Conference]], meaning they likewise avoided starting the following season on -10 points (though they would find themselves being double-relegated to the Conference North for unrelated reasons).[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/boston_united/6738469.stm Boston suffer new demotion blow] The Football League saw both cases as clubs trying to exploit a loophole, and changed the rules. From 2007–08, any club entering administration after the fourth Thursday in March would have their 10-point deduction suspended until the following season. If the club is relegated the points will be deducted from their tally at the start of next season. If the club stays up the 10 points will be taken off their final total. {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/6736997.stm|title=League closes 10-point loophole |date=9 June 2007|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 February 2010}} On 26 February 2010, [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] became the first Premier League club to enter administration. ===Football creditors rule=== In a situation of insolvency, the "football creditors rule" means that debts to other clubs or players are prioritised and must be paid in full before the club is eligible to compete again in the league.{{cite web|last=Plainer|first=Adam|title=Paying by the rules|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/paying-by-the-rules/1003055.article|work=[[The Lawyer]]|accessdate=31 May 2010|date=11 January 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100512172003/http://www.thelawyer.com/paying-by-the-rules/1003055.article| archivedate= 12 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} The [[Enterprise Act 2002]] made reforms to the insolvency act and, from 15 September 2003, the altered procedures for administration were implemented.{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions about the Enterprise Act: Company|url=http://www.insolvency.gov.uk/faq/faqeactc.htm|publisher=[[Insolvency Service|The Insolvency Service]]|accessdate=31 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100505053545/http://www.insolvency.gov.uk/faq/faqeactc.htm| archivedate= 5 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} Most notably it abolished the Crown's preferential right to recover unpaid taxes ahead of other creditors.{{cite web|title=Enterprise Act changes to be introduced in June|url=http://www.out-law.com/page-3501|date=24 April 2003|work=[[OUT-LAW]]|accessdate=31 May 2010}} As such, [[HM Revenue and Customs]] (HMRC) is now often not paid in full (between 2003 and 2010, outstanding unpaid taxes to the HMRC amounted to £30 million).{{cite news|title=Crunched creditors call time on living the dream|first=Dave|last=Conn|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/david-conn-inside-sport-blog/2010/feb/10/portsmouth-cardiff-hmrc-winding-up|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 February 2010|accessdate=13 October 2013|location=London}} This legality of the football creditors rule was challenged in 2004 in ''[[Inland Revenue Commissioners v The Wimbledon Football Club Ltd]]''. However, it was found that "full payment to football creditors (out of third party funds) ahead of preferential creditors did not infringe the provisions of section s4(4)(a) of the Act" and "differential treatment may be necessary to secure the continuation of the company's business and may be regarded as supportable".{{cite web|title=Company Voluntary Arrangements |first=John |last=Verrill |url=http://www.dundas-wilson.com/publications/dw_cms_4894.pdf |publisher=[[Dundas & Wilson]] |date=1 September 2008 |accessdate=31 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002071144/http://www.dundas-wilson.com/publications/dw_cms_4894.pdf |archivedate=2 October 2011 }} In 2011 HMRC brought another challenge to the football creditors rule in the High Court, this time on the basis that it breached fundamental principles of insolvency law, including the [[pari passu]] rule that all unsecured creditors should be paid on a proportionate basis. However, in May 2012 the court rejected the challenge as it found that the rule was not a deliberate evasion of insolvency law.{{cite news|title=HM Revenue and Customs v The Football League Ltd [2012] EWHC 1372 (Ch)|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Ch/2012/1372.html}} ===List of clubs that have entered administration=== {{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {{update-section|date=March 2017}} {| class="wikitable sortable" !Club !Entered

|- |[[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] |{{dts|2013|May|02|format=dmy}}{{cite web|title=Relegated club goes into administration|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22383276|accessdate=2 May 2013 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=2 March 2013}} | |[[Football League Two|League Two]] | |} ==Scotland== Following the adoption of a points sanction in the [[The Football League|English Football League]], a similar rule was proposed for adoption by the [[Scottish Premier League]] (SPL) in December 2003.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/3331583.stm|title=SPL debate administration penalty |date=18 December 2003|publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 March 2010}} It was announced in January 2004 that SPL clubs going into administration in the [[2004–05 Scottish Premier League|2004–05 season]] would be subject to a 10-point deduction and be prevented from signing new players. With [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] and [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] already in administration at the time, it was decided that if "they are not in the process of coming out of administration by 31 May", the deduction would be applied at the start of the following season.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/3418773.stm|title=Dundee face point deduction|date=22 January 2004|publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 March 2010}} Furthermore, the [[Scottish Football Association]] would not allow clubs in administration to play in European competition.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/3415935.stm |title=Uefa blow for cash-strapped clubs |date=21 January 2004 |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 March 2010}} Both Motherwell and Dundee met the required conditions to avoid the deduction of points.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dundee/3749583.stm |title=Dundee rescue plan agreed |date=26 May 2004 |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 March 2010}} The 10 point penalty was subsequently applied to [[Gretna F.C.|Gretna]] in the 2007–08 season and [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in 2011–12. Although the [[Scottish Football League]] (SFL) had no automatic deduction of points for clubs going into administration, it reserved the right to "deduct championship points before or during a season and/or to impose a player registration embargo on any club".{{cite book|title=Scottish Football League Handbook 2009–2010|publisher=[[Scottish Football League]]|pages=148|chapter=Constitution and Rules |url=http://www.scottishfootballleague.com/res/documents/SFL/SFLHandbook/SFL%20Constitution%20and%20Rules2.pdf}} This meant that its penalties for insolvency varied; [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] were docked 25 points in the 2010–11 season because it was the second time they had entered administration in a relatively short period.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/scottish-football/10365208/SPFL-clubs-that-go-into-administration-could-be-relegated.html |title=SPFL clubs that go into administration could be relegated |first=Ewing |last=Grahame |work=Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=9 October 2013 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} The SFL also had the power to place a team in the bottom tier ([[Scottish Football League Third Division|Third Division]]) if there were any doubts that the club could fulfill their fixtures for the forthcoming season.{{cite web |title=Livi relegated to Division Three |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/livingston/8179998.stm |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 November 2011 |date=5 August 2009}} The [[administration and liquidation of The Rangers Football Club Plc]] prompted much discussion in Scotland about what sanctions (if any) are appropriate for an insolvent club.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17975013 |title=SPL board can't win over Rangers decision - Stephen Thompson |date=6 May 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2013 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC}} When Rangers entered administration in February 2012, the club was docked 10 points in the [[2011–12 Scottish Premier League]]. The SPL clubs agreed to amend the penalty for administration to the greater of 10 points or one third of the club's tally in the previous season.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18263819 |title=SPL: Clubs set new financial fair play rules at Hampden meeting |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=30 May 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} Rangers attempted to agree a CVA with its creditors, but this offer was rejected by HMRC in June 2012.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18407309 |title=Rangers to re-form after creditors' deal is rejected |first1=Alasdair |last1=Lamont |first2=Chris |last2=McLaughlin |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=12 June 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} The business and assets of Rangers were instead sold to a new company. One of Rangers' assets was its membership of the SPL, but this could not be transferred without the approval of the other SPL clubs. Rangers' application for transfer was rejected by a 10–1 majority.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18703183 |title=Rangers newco refused SPL entry after chairmen vote |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=4 July 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} The SPL attempted to negotiate a deal with the SFL whereby Rangers would enter the First Division (second tier). This was rejected by SFL clubs, who instead voted for Rangers to be granted associate membership of the SFL and a place in the Third Division (fourth tier).{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18813407 |title=Rangers: Charles Green accepts Division Three vote |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=13 July 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} When the SPL and SFL merged to form the [[Scottish Professional Football League]] (SPFL) in 2013, the penalty for entering administration was standardised as 15 points. [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] entered administration days before the leagues merged and were docked 15 points for the 2013–14 season under the old SPL rules, as they had earned 44 points in the 2012–13 season.{{cite web |url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/clubs/hearts/229830-qa-what-will-happen-to-hearts-now-they-are-in-administration/ |title=Q&A: What will happen to Hearts now they are in administration? |first=Grant |last=Russell |work=STV Sport |publisher=STV |date=19 June 2013 |accessdate=18 December 2013}} ===List of clubs that have entered administration=== {{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {| class="wikitable sortable" !Club !Entered

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{infobox Organization |name = Alberta Enterprise Group |image = |size = |abbreviation = AEG |motto = Leaders in Action |formation = 2006 |type = Public policy advocacy group |headquarters = |location = [[Edmonton]], Alberta, Canada |leader_title = President |leader_name = Josh Bilyk |website = [http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/ AlbertaEnterpriseGroup.com] }} The '''Alberta Enterprise Group''' (AEG) is a member-based, non-profit business advocacy organization based in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ic.gc.ca/app/ccc/srch/nvgt.do?lang=eng&prtl=1&sbPrtl=&estblmntNo=234567134622&profile=cmpltPrfl&profileId=1921&app=sold|title=Alberta Enterprise Group|publisher=Industry Canada|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>
The organization claims its members collectively employ more than 150,000 people and generate billions in economic activity each year.<ref name=AEG>[http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/about-us ''Alberta Enterprise Group'', About us, Accessed: Feb. 3, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231054038/http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/about-us |date=December 31, 2011 }}</ref>
The organization states its mission as applying the collective experience of its members in order to solve public policy challenges and to form and promote public policy solutions and to provide forums for the exchange of ideas and best practices.<ref name=AEG/>
==History== In 2006 a group of Alberta business leaders came together to form a [[fundraising]]/[[political]] action group called Grassroots Leadership Group.<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Norris takes business approach to leadership|url=http://www.edsonleader.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?archive=true&e=1908414|publisher=''Edson Leader'' |year=2006|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> The group unsuccessfully supported [[Mark Norris (Canadian politician)|Mark Norris]] on the first [[ballot]] in his [[Progressive Conservative Association of Alberta]] leadership bid. After Norris dropped off the ballot, the group supported eventual winner [[Ed Stelmach]] on the second ballot.<ref>{{cite news|first=Calgary|last=Herald|title= Consulting company set up to finance Norris's bid|url=http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=0a181d46-2d32-466c-ac84-b3da7f7c792c|publisher=''Edmonton Journal'' |date=March 31, 2006|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref>
After the PC leadership process, Grassroots Leadership Group members decided to keep the group together as a business advocacy organization and re-branded as Alberta Enterprise Group, headed by then-Chairman [[Cal Nichols]].
Until 2013 the organization was led by Tim Shipton until his departure in November of that year.<ref name="Tim Shipton">{{cite web|title=Tim Shipton joins Rexall Sports Corp.|url=http://oilers.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=688214|website=oilers.nhl.com|publisher=Edmonton Oilers|accessdate=5 June 2014|ref=21}}</ref> Tim Shipton was previously director of the [[Progressive Conservative Association of Alberta]].<ref name=AEG/>
In February, 2014 the organization announced the appointment of Josh Bilyk as President.<ref>{{cite web|title=New leadership at business advocacy group|url=http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/new-leadership-at-business-advocacy-group-3/|website=www.albertaenterprisegroup.com|publisher=Alberta Enterprise Group|accessdate=5 June 2014|ref=22}}</ref>
==Activities== The organization has conducted several meetings over the years trying to draw more business to Canada. In 2008 AEG brought 100 of the province's business leaders to [[Washington D.C.]] to meet with congressional leaders and [[United States]] business leaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.international.alberta.ca/documents/International/Premier_Mission_to_Washington_DC.pdf|title=International Premier Mission to Washington|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> Then in 2009 the organization brought more than 60 of the province's business leaders to [[Geneva, Switzerland]] in an effort to showcase Alberta to the [[Europe]]an investment community. In both 2008 and 2009 the organization brought more than 150 businessmen and politicians from across [[North America]] to tour the [[Alberta oil sands|oil sands mining operations]]. Participants visited [[Syncrude]], [[Albian]] and CNRL's Horizon Mine.<ref name=AEG/>
In the spring of 2010, AEG organized the Alberta Connects outreach mission to [[Ottawa]]. Alberta Connects introduced AEG members to [[Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]], Finance Minister Flaherty, Environment Minister Prentice, Liberal Leader [[Michael Ignatieff]] and 55 other Members of Parliament and Senators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aimcapitalcorp.com/pages/EventReview-AlbertaConnect2010.pdf|title=Alberta Connects 2010|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref>
In 2011, the group returned to Washington, D.C. to engage U.S political leaders in a discussion on improving trade relations between Canada and the United States and ensuring market access for Canadian energy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edmontonjournal.com/2011/05/26/david-maclean-in-washington-a-guest-blog/|title=''Edmonton Journal'', David MacLean in Washington: a guest blog|accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref> In 2012, the group brought a delegation of 40 business leaders to Quebec to meet with business and political leaders in that province, purportedly to improve trade ties between the two provinces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/news/canada-connects-quebec-review|title=''ALG'', Canada Connect Quebec|accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
In 2015, the group [https://edmontonjournal.com/opinion/columnists/gary-lamphier-heres-a-new-one-alberta-firms-seek-opportunities-in-b-c organized a trade mission to British Columbia] where it met with British Columbia Energy and Mines Minister Bill Bennett, First Nations Energy & Mining Council CEO Dave Porter, and Iain Black, CEO of the Vancouver Board of Trade and others. A mission highlight was a keynote address by MEG Energy CEO Bill McCaffrey.
The organization is a strong proponent of what it calls "sustainable resource development," arguing that impediments to resource development imposed by excessive regulation hurt the Canadian economy and government revenues.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vancouversun.com/business/2035/Barbara+Yaffe+Alberta+must+satisfy+each+other+pipeline+concerns/7917453/story.html|title=''Vancouver Sun'', Barbara Yaffe: B.C., Alberta must satisfy each other's pipeline concerns|accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
The group has also been engaged in the discussion on Alberta's provincial budget, advocating spending restraint as opposed to tax increases to address a growing government deficit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://calgaryherald.com/opinion/columnists/talk+about+control+public+spending/7538139/story.html|title=''Calgary Herald'', MacLean: Let's talk about out-of-control public spending|accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
===Business taxation advocacy=== In April 2015, during the [[2015 Alberta general election campaign]] the group released a [http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/AEG-Alberta-business-tax-competitiveness-April-28-2015-final.pdf study] [https://calgaryherald.com/opinion/columnists/maclean-its-a-bad-idea-to-raise-corporate-taxes arguing that increasing business taxes would kill jobs and investment, increase consumer prices and reduce wages for workers.]
===Labour Reform=== The organization has also published information regarding [[collective bargaining]]. In December 2009 AEG released a study calling for reforms to provincial [[labour laws]], hoping to create good business climates while upholding the collective bargaining rights of workers. The paper argued that the Canada's labour laws lag behind [[Europe]], [[Australia]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. Some of the recommendations in the study included: having membership cards instead of signing petitions; requiring a quorum, and allowing unionized workers in Alberta be allowed opt out of the portion of their union dues that is spent on lobbying and political activities.<ref name=labour>{{cite web|url=http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/news/aeg-calls-for-labour-reform|title=Alberta Enterprise Group calls for Labour Reform|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> The organization supported enacting a Worker Free Choice Act (WFCA) to which would allow workers the right to choose whether or not to join or financially support a union as a condition of employment. Bob Barnetson, who is an associate professor of labour relations at Athabasca University, spoke out against the study's conclusions and how it was conducted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://albertalabour.blogspot.com/2011/01/labour-reform-courtesy-of-alberta.html|title=Labour reform courtesy of the Alberta Enterprise Group|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> However, the study was endorsed by the Merit Contractors Association, Canadian Constitution Foundation and the Canadian Federation of Independent Business.<ref name=labour/> A survey conducted by AEG also found that 65 percent believed 70 percent of employees should vote to certify or decertify a union. The poll also found that 78 percent agreed that union dues should only be spent on collective bargaining and union management instead of policy influence.
===Edmonton City Centre Airport=== Also in 2009, the organization waged a campaign to save the [[Edmonton City Centre Airport]] from closure, arguing that the facility is an economic asset and an important component of the province's health system, saying it provided $400 million in economic output annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://albertaenterprisegroup.com/Ascend_AEG_report_--_June_23rd_Final.pdf|title=Ascent AEG Report|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> The group ran a petition to keep the airport open, collecting over 1000 signatures.<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Edmonton City Centre Airport debate heats up online |url=http://www.inews880.com/Channels/Reg/LocalNews/story.aspx?ID=1108542|publisher=''iNews 880'' |date=June 30, 2009|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> After discussions about compromising and only closing one lane, Edmonton City Councillors ultimately voted to close the [[Edmonton City Centre (Blatchford Field) Airport|airport]].<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Kevin Libin: A plot to kill Edmonton's city airport?|url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/07/23/kevin-libin-a-secret-plot-to-kill-edmontons-city-airport/|publisher=''National Post'' |date=July 23, 2010|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref>
===Oil sands=== Im May 2011 AEG went to Washington, D.C. to talk about borders security, [[energy]] development and trade. Participants met with Members of the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate to discuss the pending decision on the [[Keystone XL pipeline]].<ref name=keystone>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=David MacLean in Washington: a guest blog|url=http://blogs.edmontonjournal.com/2011/05/26/david-maclean-in-washington-a-guest-blog/|publisher=''Edmonton Journal'' |date=May 26, 2011|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> The meetings noted that [[tar sands]] knowledge had increased, discussed Canada's commitment to its environment and the benefits of the oil sands to America. In December 2011, AEG led a counter-boycott of [[Chiquita Bananas]] in response to the company signing on to an anti-oil sands campaign coordinated by [[California]]-based environmental advocacy group Forest Ethics.<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Oil sands lobby fires back at Chiquita|url=http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/financialpost/story.html?id=ee91cbbd-2ec0-45e8-a73b-572b2e340f1e|publisher=''National Post'' |date=December 17, 2011|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> Chiquita later said that it would continue to use Canadian oil.<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Chiquita won't join bunch boycotting Alberta oilsands products|url=https://montrealgazette.com/business/Chiquita+join+bunch+boycotting+oilsands+products/5900976/story.html|publisher=''Montreal Gazette'' |date=December 22, 2011|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref> Levi-Strauss and Timberland were also targeted by AEG in the boycott of the boycotters, but were later taken down from the page after the companies said they would not boycott Canadian oil.<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Canadians Urged to boycott GAP, Levi-Strauss and Timberland|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/681005/canadians-urged-to-boycott-gap-levi-strauss-and-timberland|publisher=''News Wire'' |date=August 27, 2010|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Alberta business group applauds Gap, Levi clarification|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/579865/alberta-business-group-applauds-gap-levi-clarification|publisher=''News Wire'' |date=August 31, 2010|accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = A-ryabinskiy.jpg | image_size = | name = Andrey Ryabinskiy | caption = | birth_name = Andrey Mikhailovich Ryabinskiy | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1973|7|17}} | birth_place = USSR | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Russian | residence = Moscow, Russia | education = | occupation = Businessman, boxing promoter | known_for = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relatives = | website = |awards = }} '''Andrey Mikhailovich Ryabinskiy''' (born July 17, 1973, Moscow, USSR) – [[Russia]]n entrepreneur, founder and chairman of the board of directors of LLC [[MIC (organization)|Moskovsky Ipotechny Centr Group]]. President of the promotional company World of Boxing. Vice President of the Professional [[Boxing Federation of Russia]].
==Biography== Andrey Ryabinskiy was born and raised in Moscow.
===Education=== In 1998, Andrey graduated from secondary school No.1158 in Moscow, and in 1998, from the G.V. Plekhanov Russian Academy of Economics as a specialist in Cybernetics. From 2009 to 2011, he studied at the [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration|Academy of National Economy under the Government of the Russian Federation]], where he earned a [[Doctor of Business Administration|DBA]].
===Professional Activities=== As a student, Andrey started working in a major Moscow real estate company. There, he met Aleksandr Kopylkov, and in 1999 they founded MIC Group together. Having initially focused exclusively on real-estate work, the company began investing in housing construction and related sectors, and from 2005 began building housing independently. In 2012, Andrey became chairman of the board of directors of MIC Group, which is one of the top 3 property developers in "New Moscow"and Moscow Region and took 12th place in [[RBK Group|RBC]] magazine's TOP 30 ranking of Russia's biggest property developers in 2013<ref>[http://rway.ru/news/57768 ГК «МИЦ» вошла в список крупнейших девелоперов России // RWAY.Ru, 02.06.2014]</ref>.
==Sports Projects==
As a youth Andrey was keen on [[boxing]], in which he gained Candidate of Sport and Master of Sport qualifications.
In 2012 and 2013, he was a General Partner of Khimki [[Basketball]] Club<ref>[http://news.sportbox.ru/Vidy_sporta/Basketbol/spbnews_NI355929_Sponsori-nachali-reshati-problemi-Himok Спонсоры начали решать проблемы «Химок» // Sportbox.ru]</ref>.
Since 2012 he has been a Vice President of the Professional Boxing Federation of Russia.
On October 5, 2013, Andrey Ryabinskiy together with [[Rosneft]] organized a boxing match between [[Vladimir Klichko]] and [[Alexander Povetkin]] under the auspices of [[World Boxing Association|WBA]], [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]], [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] and [[International Boxing Organization|IBO]]<ref>[http://www.kommersant.ru/pda/kommersant.html?id=2178069 Бой для миллионов // «Коммерсантъ», 25.04.13]</ref>. The budget for the Klichko vs. Povetkin fight was USD 25 million and the television rights were sold worldwide to broadcasters including RTL, HBO and Russia's Channel One. According to Ryabinskiy, it was not a commercial project for him: “I understand that when compared to the earnings, whatever I do I’m throwing my money down the drain by organizing this fight<ref>[http://sport.rbc.ru/news/177818/ А.Рябинский: Оплачиваем бой Поветкин — Кличко с «Роснефтью» равноправно и хотим показать его на Первом канале // «РБК-Спорт», 17.07.2013]</ref>. But I just wanted to organize a world-class fight". Ryabinskiy also noted that he wants to hep Moscow become an international boxing center like New York, Las Vegas and Hamburg<ref>[http://www.vedomosti.ru/companies/news/13762871/rosneft-vyjdet-na-ring Бой Кличко и Поветкина обойдется «Роснефти» в $12,5 млн // «Ведомости», 03.07.2013]</ref>.
In 2013, Andrey created and headed up the promotionalcompany World of Boxing, which became part of MIC Group<ref>[http://www.championat.com/boxing/news-1761139-aleksandr-povetkin-podpisal-kontrakt-s-novoj-promouterskoj-kompaniej.html Александр Поветкин подписал контракт с новой промоутерской компанией // Championat.com, 14.02.2014]</ref>. The Center has signed contracts with leading boxers including Alexander Povetkin, [[Denis Lebedev]], [[Grigory Drozd]], [[Rakhim Chakhkiev]], [[Eduard Troyanovsky]] and [[Manuel Charr]] to become Europe's biggest boxing promoter<ref>[http://www.championat.com/boxing/news-1970602-mir-boksa-podpisala-kontrakt-s-bojcom-oderzhavshim-15-dosrochnykh-pobed-podrjad.html «Мир бокса» подписала контракт с бойцом одержавшим 15 досрочных побед подряд // Championat.com, 01.11.2014]</ref>.
In 2014, the World of Boxing promotional company organized a number of major championship fights<ref>[http://itar-tass.com/opinions/interviews/1599682 Андрей РЯБИНСКИЙ: несмотря на поражение от Кличко, Поветкин — один из выдающихся боксеров в своей весовой категории // ТАСС, 26.06.2014]</ref>. In 2015, Ryabinskiy won a court case against the legendary boxing promoter Don King, who was responsible for the cancellation of а fight between WBA world champion Denis Lebedev and Guillermo Jones.Ryabinskiy promised to invest the USD 1.6 mln compensation payout in "training Russian boxers"<ref>[http://www.vedomosti.ru/sport/news/38961771/biznesmen-ryabinskij-otsudil-16-mln-za-sorvannyj-boj-mezhdu Андрей Рябинский отсудил $1,6 млн у Дона Кинга за сорванный бой Лебедев — Джонс // «Ведомости», 03.02.2015]</ref><ref>[http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2659825 Дон Кинг проиграл на своем ринге // «Коммерсантъ», 04.02.2015]</ref>. In 2018, Ryabinskiy won USD 4.3 mln in a dispute over the fight between [[Alexander Povetkin]] and [[Deontay Wilder]], which was cancelled in 2016<ref>[https://rsport.ria.ru/fights/20180420/1135760072.html Суд присудил Поветкину $4,3 млн, замороженные после отменённого боя с Уайлдером // Р-Спорт, 20.04.2018]</ref>.
==Achievements and awards== In 2011, was a prizewinner in the Persona No.1 category of the annual international Real Estate Market Records awards<ref>[http://realty.rbc.ru/company_news/24/06/2011/562949980514682.shtml Лучшие клиентоориентированные компании стали № 1 на рынке недвижимости // «РБК-Недвижимость», 24.06.2011]</ref>.
In 2012, placed 360th in [[Kommersant]]'s Top 1000 Regional Enterprise Managers ranking as chairman of the board of MIC Group<ref>[http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2025260 Рейтинг «Топ-1000 региональных руководителей предприятий» // «Коммерсантъ», 19.09.2012]</ref>.
In July 2013, placed 5th in Medialogiya's TOP 10 Businessmenranking after organizing the Klichko vs. Povetkin fight<ref>[http://www.bfm.ru/news/221598 Прощание Абрамовича с Чукоткой оказалось в центре внимания // BFM.ru, 08/07/2013]</ref>.
In 2014, was named Man of the Year by the [[World Boxing Council]] (WBC)<ref>[http://wbcboxing.com/wbceng/news/3925-andrey-ryabinsky-wbc-man-of-the-year Andrey Ryabinsky — WBC Man Of The Year // wbcboxing.com, 07.01.2015]</ref>.
In 2014, won the Russian Boxing Star award in the Man of the Year category.
In 2016, set a world sniper record in the "Group of Five Shots in a Row" discipline. In 2017, set a world sniper record in precision at long distance – 4,210 m<ref>[http://www.sovsport.ru/news/text-item/912930 Андрей Рябинский установил мировой рекорд в снайпинге // Советский Спорт, 07.01.2015]</ref><ref>[https://www.gazeta.ru/sport/news/2017/10/03/n_10645621.shtml Глава «Мира Бокса» Рябинский установил рекорд по стрельбе на дальность // Газета.Ру, 03.10.2017]</ref>.
In 2018, took 5th place in an international tournament of sniper teams from special forces and 2nd place in the F-OPEN category of the F-class discipline at the Russian High-Precision Shooting Open<ref>[http://allboxing.ru/news/20180507-0921/andrey-ryabinskiy-zanyal-vtoroe-mesto-na-pervenstve-rossii-po-strelbe Андрей Рябинский занял второе место на первенстве России по стрельбе // Allboxing.ru, 07.05.2018]</ref>.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

'''Bankruptcy prediction''' is the art of predicting [[bankruptcy]] and various measures of [[financial distress]] of public firms. It is a vast area of finance and accounting research. The importance of the area is due in part to the relevance for [[creditor]]s and [[investor]]s in evaluating the likelihood that a firm may go bankrupt.
The quantity of research is also a function of the availability of data: for public firms which went bankrupt or did not, numerous accounting ratios that might indicate danger can be calculated, and numerous other potential explanatory variables are also available. Consequently, the area is well-suited for testing of increasingly sophisticated, data-intensive [[forecasting]] approaches.
==History== The history of bankruptcy prediction includes application of numerous statistical tools which gradually became available, and involves deepening appreciation of various pitfalls in early analyses. Research is still published that suffers pitfalls that have been understood for many years.
Bankruptcy prediction has been a subject of formal analysis since at least 1932, when FitzPatrick published a study of 20 pairs of firms, one failed and one surviving, matched by date, size and industry, in ''The Certified Public Accountant''. He did not perform statistical analysis as is now common, but he thoughtfully interpreted the ratios and trends in the ratios. His interpretation was effectively a complex, multiple variable analysis.
In 1967, [[William Beaver]] applied [[t-tests]] to evaluate the importance of individual accounting ratios within a similar pair-matched sample.
In 1968, in the first formal multiple variable analysis, [[Edward I. Altman]] applied [[multiple discriminant analysis]] within a pair-matched sample. One of the most prominent early models of bankruptcy prediction is the [[Altman Z-score]], which is still applied today.
In 1980, [[James Ohlson]] applied [[logit regression]] in a much larger sample that did not involve pair-matching.
==Modern methods== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2014}} Survival methods are now applied.
Option valuation approaches involving stock price variability have been developed. Under structural models,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fields.utoronto.ca/programs/scientific/09-10/finance/courses/hurdnotes2.pdf|title=Structural Modes of Credit Risk|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> a default event is deemed to occur for a firm when its assets reach a sufficiently low level compared to its liabilities.
[[Neural network model]]s and other sophisticated models have been tested on bankruptcy prediction.
Modern methods applied by business information companies surpass the annual accounts content and also consider current events like age, judgements, bad press, payment incidents and payment experiences from creditors.
==Comparison of differing approaches ==
The latest research within the field of Bankruptcy and Insolvency Prediction compares various differing approaches, modelling techniques, and individual models to ascertain whether any one technique is superior to its counterparts.
Jackson and Wood (2013) provides an excellent discussion of the literature to date, including an empirical evaluation of 15 popular models from the existing literature. These models range from the univariate models of Beaver through the multidimensional models of Altman and Ohlson, and continuing to more recent techniques which include option valuation approaches. They find that models based on market data - such as an option valuation approach - outperform those earlier models which rely heavily on accounting numbers.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0890838913000498 | doi=10.1016/j.bar.2013.06.009 | volume=45 | title=The performance of insolvency prediction and credit risk models in the UK: A comparative study | journal=The British Accounting Review | pages=183–202}}</ref>
Zhang, Wang, and Ji (2013) proposed a novel [[rule-based system]] to solve bankruptcy prediction problem. The whole procedure consists of the following four stages: first, sequential [[forward selection]] was used to extract the most important features; second, a rule-based model was chosen to fit the given dataset since it can present physical meaning; third, a genetic [[ant colony algorithm]] (GACA) was introduced; the fitness scaling strategy and the chaotic operator were incorporated with GACA, forming a new algorithm—fitness-scaling chaotic GACA (FSCGACA), which was used to seek the optimal parameters of the rule-based model; and finally, the [[Cross-validation_(statistics)#k-fold_cross-validation|stratified K-fold cross-validation]] technique was used to enhance the generalization of the model.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zhang|first=Yudong|author2=Shuihua Wang |author3=Genlin Ji |title=A Rule-Based Model for Bankruptcy Prediction Based on an Improved Genetic Ant Colony Algorithm|journal=Mathematical Problems in Engineering|date=2013|volume=2013|doi=10.1155/2013/753251|url=http://downloads.hindawi.com/journals/mpe/2013/753251.pdf|page=753251}}</ref>
==References== {{More footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{reflist}} *[[FitzPatrick 1932]] *Beaver 1966. Financial ratios predictors of failure. ''[[Journal of Accounting Research]], 4 (Supplement), p. 71-111. *Beaver 1968 *{{cite journal | last1 = Altman | first1 = Edward I | year = 1968 | title = Financial ratios, discriminant analysis and the prediction of corporate bankruptcy | url = | journal = [[Journal of Finance]] | volume = 23 | issue = 4| pages = 589–609 }} *Ohlson, James. 1980. *{{cite journal | last1 = Balcaen | first1 = Sofie | last2 = Ooghe | first2 = Hubert | year = 2006 | title = 35 years of studies on business failure: an overview of the classic statistical methodologies and their related problems | url = | journal = [[British Accounting Review]] | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 63–93 }} *Zmijewski, Mark E. 1984. "Methodological issues related to the estimation of financial distress prediction models". ''[[Journal of Accounting Research]]'' 22 (Supplement), p. 59-86. *{{cite journal | last1 = Jackson | first1 = Richard | last2 = Wood | first2 = Anthony | year = 2013 | title = The Performance of Insolvency Prediction and Credit Risk Models in the UK: A Comparative Study | url = | journal = The British Accounting Review | volume = 45 | issue = 3| pages = 183–202 }} * {{cite journal | last=Danilov | first=Konstantin | title=Corporate Bankruptcy: Assessment, Analysis and Prediction of Financial Distress, Insolvency, and Failure | journal=SSRN Electronic Journal |url=http://www.ssrn.com/abstract=2467580| publisher=Elsevier BV | year=2014 | issn=1556-5068 | doi=10.2139/ssrn.2467580 | ref=harv}}

'''CPAmerica, Inc.''' is one of the largest associations of independent [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]] firms in the [[United States]]. It includes more than 74 firms with almost 170 offices in 40 states. The total staff is more than 3,900 employees, which includes more than 690 partners. Member firms vary in size from $2 million to $50 million in firm revenues, averaging $9.8 million. The number of personnel ranges from 15 to 325.
Only one member is accepted to the association in each {{convert|50|mi|km|adj=on}} radius except for a few major cities. Member firms receive practice management suggestions, information sharing between firms, [[Continuing professional education|CPE]] training, marketing products and access to national consultants. They communicate via discussion lists, conference calls, an online sharing library and regular nationwide conferences and regional meetings.
CPAmerica is a member of [[Crowe Global]]. The international network includes 752 offices worldwide with almost 40,000 employees.
==History== The association was founded in 1978 by eight firms as Accounting Firms Associated, Inc., and its headquarters was later established in [[Gainesville, Florida]]. By 1990, it included 43 firms. In 1998, with 60 members, it formed a strategic alliance with Crowe Horwath International (now known as Crowe Global). The name was changed to CPAmerica International in 2000. The following year, it moved into a {{convert|16000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} headquarters building in [[Alachua, Florida]]. In 2012, the headquarters moved again to downtown Gainesville. In 2018, the name changed to CPAmerica, Inc.
==Affiliates==
[https://www.crowe.com/ '''Crowe Global'''], an international group with headquarters in [[New York City]], has worldwide membership that expands to 216 independent accounting and advisory firms in more than 130 countries, and has a combined firm revenue of $3.8 billion.
'''[[CPAConnect]]''' was established by CPAmerica in 1994 as an alliance made up of smaller firms and sole practitioners. It has nearly 175 members in almost 40 states, [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Mexico]]. Total revenue of all member firms is approximately $155 million, and average size is seven employees, which includes two partners.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{technical|date=September 2011}} [[Image:closedrestaurant.jpg|thumb|250px|A closed restaurant in [[Gananoque, Ontario]]]]
'''Commercial insolvency in Canada''' has options and procedures that are distinct from those available in consumer [[insolvency]] proceedings. It is governed by the following statutes:
:* The ''[[Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act]]'' ("BIA") <ref>{{Cite web|title = Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. B-3) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/index.html | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref> :* The ''[[Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act]]'' ("CCAA") <ref>{{Cite web|title = Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. C-36) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-36/index.html | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref> :* The ''[[Winding-Up and Restructuring Act]]'' <ref>{{Cite web|title = Winding-up and Restructuring Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. W-11) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/W-11/index.html | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref>
The following discussion concentrates on insolvency as it applies to corporations, but the rules apply to individuals and other entities involved in commercial matters as well, with necessary modifications.
==Financial difficulties prior to insolvency==
Provincial legislation under the [[property and civil rights]] power of the [[Constitution Act, 1867]] regulates the resolution of financial difficulties that occur before the onset of insolvency, and the BIA incorporates many of them by reference in the application of its provisions. Notable legislation is in effect for governing:
:* absconding debtors<ref>{{Cite web|title = Absconding Debtors Act (Ontario), R.S.O. 1990, c. A.2 | url = http://www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes_90a02_e.htm}}</ref> :* [[fraudulent conveyance]]s<ref>{{Cite web|title = Fraudulent Conveyances Act (Ontario), R.S.O. 1990, c. F.29 | url = http://www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes_90f29_e.htm}}</ref> :* relief of creditors<ref>{{Cite web|title = Creditors’ Relief Act, 2010 (Ontario) , S.O. 2010, c. 16, Sch. 4 | url = http://www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes_10c16b_e.htm}}</ref> :* seizure of assets<ref>{{Cite web|title = Execution Act (Ontario), R.S.O. 1990, c. E.24 | url = http://www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes_90e24_e.htm}}</ref>
As well, corporate directors have a statutory duty of loyalty to the corporation and a duty of care to all of its stakeholders. It follows that directors have a duty to ensure that their corporation carries on business only if it can meet its liabilities as they become due and if there is a reasonable expectation of newly incurred obligations being satisfied.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Scott Bomhof, [[Torys LLP]]|title = Duties of Directors in the Insolvency Zone | url = http://www.torys.com/Publications/Documents/Publication%20PDFs/AR2010-24.pdf|accessdate = 2011-12-14}}</ref>
==Alternatives to resolving financial difficulties==
Where a commercial debtor is experiencing financial difficulties, it is generally in his best interests to work with the secured lenders.<ref>{{Cite web|author = D. Robb English, Paul Bowers and David Carson |title = Turnarounds: Dealing with the Secured Lender | url= http://www.airdberlis.com/Templates/Articles/articleFiles/315/Turnaround_seminar.pdf | publisher = Aird & Berlis | date = 2004-09-27 | accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref> The following options may be considered in order to seek a resolution to the matter:
:* informal compromise with creditors :* out-of court [[restructuring|restructuring agreements]] <ref>{{Cite web|author = Milly Chow |title = Out-of-Court Restructurings | url= http://www.blakes.com/english/view_bulletin.asp?ID=4342 | publisher = [[Blake, Cassels & Graydon]] | date = 2010-11-16 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}}</ref> :* plans of arrangement under the [[Canada Business Corporations Act]] or similar provincial corporations legislation <ref>{{Cite web|title = CBCA, S. 192 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-44/page-64.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Policy Concerning Arrangements Under Section 192 of the CBCA | url= https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/cd-dgc.nsf/eng/cs01073.html | publisher = Industry Canada | date = 2010-01-04 | accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | author = Peter Rubin |title = Arrangement Provisions of the Canada Business Corporations Act | url= http://www.blakes.com/english/view_bulletin.asp?ID=4341 | publisher = [[Blake, Cassels & Graydon]] | date = 2010-11-16 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Restructuring Under the Business Corporations Act | url= http://www.fmc-law.com/upload/en/publications/Restructuring%20Under%20the%20Business%20Corporations%20Act_Sept09.pdf | publisher = [[Fraser Milner Casgrain]] | date = September 2009 | accessdate = 2011-09-08}}</ref> :* the debtor making an assignment for the general benefit of creditors under the pertinent provincial legislation <ref>{{Cite web|title = Assignments and Preferences Act (Ontario), R.S.O. 1990, c. A.33 | url= http://www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes_90a33_e.htm | accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref> :* the creditor(s) securing appointment of a [[Receivership|receiver or interim receiver]] to seize and administer any of the debtor's property <ref>{{Cite web| author = Aubrey E. Kaufman and R. Graham Phoenix |title = Interim Receivers under the BIA: What practicality demands ... for now | url = http://www.fasken.com/files/Publication/b2d58d89-0bad-44a6-97b2-14f728357d13/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/85794bc1-84d1-4461-8af8-2521f3590497/Interim_Receivers_Under_the_BIA.pdf| publisher = [[Fasken Martineau]] | date = 2007-10-31 | accessdate = 2011-09-12}}</ref> :* the debtor making a proposal to creditors (known as a "Division I proposal") <ref>{{Cite web|title = Process for Division I Proposals | url = http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/bsf-osb.nsf/eng/br02052.html | publisher = OSB | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref> :* the debtor making an application under the CCAA to make a compromise or arrangement with its creditors <ref>{{Cite web|title = The Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act | url = http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/bsf-osb.nsf/eng/br02284.html | publisher = OSB | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref> :* an insolvent debtor making an assignment under the BIA for the general benefit of his creditors<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 49 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-23.html#h-22}}</ref> :* creditors applying for a bankruptcy order where the debtor owes at least $1,000 and has committed an act of bankruptcy
All options other than the first four have the effect of staying any proceedings that can be brought against the debtor.
Insolvent persons have the choice of making an assignment immediately, or to seek protection from creditors in order to reorganize their affairs and continue as a going concern. For the latter option, companies owing less than $5 million generally opt to file a Division I proposal, while those owing more can also opt for the CCAA proceeding.
==Entities subject to insolvency regime==
With certain exceptions, the ''BIA'' covers a wide range of entities:
:* it covers anyone who has resided or carried on business in Canada :* it "includes a partnership, an unincorporated association, a corporation, a cooperative society or a cooperative organization, the successors of a partnership, of an association, of a corporation, of a society or of an organization and the heirs, executors, liquidators of the succession, administrators or other legal representatives of a person;"<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 2, definition of "person" | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-1.html#h-2}}</ref> but :* it does not apply to banks, insurance companies, trust companies, loan companies, and railways.<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 2, definition of "corporation" | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-1.html#h-2}}</ref> :* Insolvent financial institutions are governed by the ''Winding-Up and Restructuring Act'' <ref>{{Cite web|title = Winding-Up and Restructuring Act, S. 6(1) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/W-11/page-3.html#h-3}}</ref> and insolvent railways by the ''Canada Transportation Act''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Canada Transportation Act, S. 106 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-10.4/page-33.html#h-58}}</ref> :* partners in a partnership may be placed into bankruptcy with that partnership,<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 43 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/section-43.html}}</ref> but that can only occur where the partnership is located in one of the common-law jurisdictions; the ''[[Civil Code of Quebec]]'' defines partnership property as being a patrimony independent from its partners<ref>{{cite web|author = Martin Boodman|title = Who Owns a Quebec Partnership?|url = http://news.mccarthy.ca/en/news_template.asp?pub_code=5201&news_code=1435&single_page=1|publisher = [[McCarthy Tétrault]]|date = November 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author= Alexandra Popovici|year= 2013|title= Québec's Partnership: Une Société Distincte|url= http://digitalcommons.law.lsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1101&context=jcls|journal= Journal of Civil Law Studies|publisher= [[Louisiana State University Law Center]]|volume= 6|issue= 1|pages= 339{{endash}}372|doi= |pmc= |pmid= |accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite CanLII|litigants=Ferme CGR enr., s.e.n.c. (Syndic de)|link=|year=2010|court=qcca|num=719|format=|pinpoint=|parallelcite=|date=2010-04-16|courtname=|juris=}}{{fr icon}}</ref> :* The ''Farm Debt Mediation Act'' provides that farmers cannot be forced into bankruptcy, but they can make a voluntary assignment.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Farm Debt Mediation Act, SS. 12-13 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/F-2.27/page-4.html#h-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Farm Debt Mediation Act, S. 14 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/F-2.27/page-5.html}}</ref>
The CCAA covers insolvent companies (together with their affiliates) with debts greater than $5 million.<ref>{{Cite web|title = CCAA, S. 3 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-36/page-2.html#h-3}}</ref>
The ''Winding-Up and Restructuring Act'', in addition to its application to financial institutions, also offers a little-used alternative to the BIA for certain groups of insolvent companies.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Winding-Up and Restructuring Act, S. 6(1) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/W-11/page-3.html#h-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Welling|first=Bruce L.|author2=Thomas G. W. Telfer|date=September 1, 2008|title=The Winding-Up and Restructuring Act: Realigning Insolvency's Orphan to the Modern Law Reform Process|journal=Banking & Finance Law Review|volume=24|page=233|ssrn=1309703|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Settlement of the insolvent person's estate==
The trustee/receiver/monitor must first realize the amount of the proceeds from the property that is available for payment to the different classes of creditors, and different rules apply according to the type of proceeding. They are summarized as follows:
{| class="wikitable" |- |+ '''Starting with the property under the possession or control of the insolvent person''' ! scope="col" width="200" | Type ! scope="col" width="75"| Notice of intention, or proposal<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 66 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-37.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 66.4 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-47.html}}</ref> ! scope="col" width="75"| Bankruptcy<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 67 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-47.html#h-26}}</ref> ! scope="col" width="75"| Receivership ! scope="col" width="75"| CCAA |- valign="top" | Held in trust for another person | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Exempt from execution or seizure | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Income tax refunds for the fiscal year of the event | Add | Add | Add | |- valign="top" | Such powers over property as are exercised for the insolvent person's own benefit | Add | Add | Add | |- valign="top" | Garnishments for enforcing notices of assessment for income tax, CPP and EI liability | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Withholding taxes deducted at source | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Funds constituting a deemed trust for the Crown (other than for garnishments and withholding taxes deducted at source) | | | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Third party's property in possession of bankrupt<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 81 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-57.html}}</ref> | | Exclude | | |- valign="top" | Goods shipped in 30 days prior to the event, and still unpaid<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 81.1 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-57.html}}</ref> | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Produce of farmer, fisherman or aquaculturist shipped in 15 days prior to the event, and still unpaid<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 81.2 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-58.html}}</ref> | Exclude | Exclude | Exclude | |- valign="top" | Copyrights and manuscripts for works not yet published<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 83(1) | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-62.html}}</ref> | | Revert to owner | | |- valign="top" | Property transferred at undervalue<ref>{{Cite web|title = BIA, S. 95 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-3/page-65.html}}</ref> | Add | Add | Add | Add<ref>{{Cite web|title = CCAA, S. 36.1 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-36/page-22.html#h-12}}</ref> |}
The estate is then settled, using the priority of claims outlined in the [[Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act|BIA]].
==Creation of security interests==
It is in the lender's or supplier's best interest to minimize his financial exposure should his client experience financial difficulties. To that end, there is a range of remedies available to establish his status as a secured (vs unsecured) creditor under both provincial and federal legislation.<ref>{{Cite web |author = John R. Sandrelli, Christopher J. Ramsay and Anjili I. Bahadoorsingh |title = Remedies under Security Interests in Canada: An Overview |url = http://www.fmc-law.com/upload/en/publications/archive/12619_Remedies_under_Security_IBA_pdf.PDF |publisher = [[Fraser Milner Casgrain]] |date = 2002-09-18 |accessdate = 2011-09-13 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120329040825/http://www.fmc-law.com/upload/en/publications/archive/12619_Remedies_under_Security_IBA_pdf.PDF |archivedate = 2012-03-29 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Federal Security Interests: Contract #99-08-2 | url= http://dalspace.library.dal.ca/bitstream/handle/10222/10278/Fraser%20Milner%20Casgrain%20Research%20Security%20Interests%20EN.pdf?sequence=1 | publisher = [[Fraser Milner Casgrain]] under contract to the Law Commission of Canada| date = June 2000 | accessdate = 2011-09-14}}</ref>
In the [[common law]] provinces, security interests are created through the registration of [[mortgage law|mortgages and charges]] against the real property concerned. In Quebec, this is done by way of [[hypothec]]s against immoveable property.
For personal property (moveable property in Quebec), secured creditors create their security interests through registration under the ''[[Personal Property Security Act (Canada)|Personal Property Security Act]]'' ("PPSA") in force in their province, or under the ''[[Civil Code of Quebec|Civil Code]]'' in Quebec by way of [[hypothec]] through the ''Registre des droits personnels et réels mobiliers''.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Kiriakoula Hatzikiriako |title = An attempt to "demystify" Québec secured transactions law (Part I) | url= http://www.mcmillan.ca/Files/ARTICLE_An%20attempt%20to%20demystify_ABA_E_0610.pdf | publisher = ABA Commercial Law Newsletter as reprinted by [[McMillan LLP]] | date = Summer 2010 | accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Registre des droits personnels et réels mobiliers | url= http://www.justice.gouv.qc.ca/english/programmes/rdprm-a.htm| accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref> Banks can also create security interests under SS. 426-427 of the [[Canada Bank Act|Bank Act]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bank Act (S.C. 1991, c. 46), S. 426 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-1.01/page-125.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Bank Act (S.C. 1991, c. 46), S. 427 | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-1.01/page-126.html}}</ref> which normally have priority over PPSA registrations.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Rebecca M. Morse |title = Priority Disputes between the Bank Act and Provincial PPSA Legislation | url= http://www.farris.com/images/uploads/RMM_-_Article_-_Priority_Disputes_Between_the_Bank_Act_and_Provincial_PPSA_Legislation.pdf | publisher = Farris, Vaughan, Wills & Murphy LLP | accessdate = 2011-09-13}}</ref> However, as noted by the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in ''[[Bank of Montreal v. Innovation Credit Union]]'', with regard to unperfected security interests, this depends on the provisions of the PPSA in effect in the province concerned.
There can be complex interplay between insolvency law and other legal regimes, such as [[admiralty law]].<ref>{{Cite web|author = Robert A. Margolis and Christopher J. Giaschi |title = Priorities and Bankruptcy in Admiralty | url= http://www.admiraltylaw.com/papers/bankruptcy.pdf | date = April 2002 | accessdate = 2011-09-22}}</ref>
In the [[common law]] provinces and territories, legislation in place for specific security interests is as follows:
