{{Infobox person |name=Rahim Fazal |image=Rahim Fazal Headshot 2015.jpg |caption=Fazal in 2015 }}
'''Rahim Fazal''' is a Canadian-born technology entrepreneur. He is notable for co-founding Involver, a provider of social media management software. Involver was co-founded by Fazal and Noah Horton in [[San Francisco]] in 2007 and was acquired by [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] on July 10, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ricadela|first1=Aaron|title=Oracle Buys Involver to Expand in Social-Media Tools|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-10/oracle-buys-involver-to-expand-in-business-social-media-tools|website=Bloomberg Business|publisher=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=28 July 2015|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911175220/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-10/oracle-buys-involver-to-expand-in-business-social-media-tools|archivedate=11 September 2014|df=}}</ref>
Involver was the technology platform that powered the first sponsorship of a [[Facebook]] Page.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ives|first1=Nat|title='Us Weekly' Sells Facebook Fan Page Ad to State Farm|url=http://adage.com/article/media/weekly-sells-facebook-fan-page-ad-state-farm/136214/|website=AdAge|publisher=Advertising Age}}</ref> Facebook partnered with Involver to build applications for large events like Election Day,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Grove|first1=Jennifer|title=Facebook Helps You Find Your Polling Place|url=http://mashable.com/2010/11/01/where-to-vote/|website=Mashable|publisher=Mashable|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> the [[FIFA World Cup]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Calderón|first1=Sara Inés|title=Facebook, Involver Launch FIFA World Cup Leaderboard|url=http://www.adweek.com/socialtimes/facebook-involver-launch-fifa-world-cup-leaderboard/239928?red=if|website=AdWeek|publisher=AdWeek|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> and the [[Super Bowl]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Constine|first1=Josh|title=Watch 2012 Super Bowl Commercials Now With Facebook + USA Today’s Ad Meter|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/02/03/watch-super-bowl-ads/|website=TechCrunch|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref>
Fazal and co-founder Horton were named to Inc. Magazine’s Top 30 Entrepreneurs Under 30 list in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=30 Under 30: 2008|url=http://www.inc.com/30under30/2008/profile/2930-fzaalhorton.html|website=Inc.|publisher=Inc. Magazine|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> He received an Empact Award from Startup America and the Kauffman Foundation at the [[White House]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gerber|first1=Scott|title=Announcing a Live Chat With Involver Founder Rahim Fazal|url=http://mashable.com/2013/01/09/live-chat-announcer-involver/|website=Mashable|publisher=Mashable|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> He was named one of the Top 40 Under 40 by the San Francisco Business Times in 2013<ref>{{cite web|last1=Riddell|first1=Lindsay|title=Business Times names 40 Under 40 for 2013|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2013/02/business-times-names-40-under-40-for.html|website=San Francisco Business Times|publisher=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref> and one of the Top 25 Digital Thought Leaders by iMedia.<ref>{{cite web|title=iMedia 25 - 2009 Internet Marketing Leaders and Innovators|url=http://www.imediaconnection.com/iMedia25/2009/people/Rahim-Fazal/|website=iMedia|publisher=iMedia|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref>
Fazal is the holder of an MBA from the [[Ivey Business School]]. He was the youngest person to be accepted to the program without a pre-requisite undergraduate degree.<ref>{{cite web|title=iMedia 25 - 2009 Internet Marketing Leaders and Innovators|url=http://www.imediaconnection.com/iMedia25/2009/people/Rahim-Fazal/|website=iMedia|publisher=iMedia|accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref>

SIMA Iquitos | homepage = {{URL|http://www.sima.com.pe/}} | footnotes = }} '''Servicios Industriales de la Marina S.A.''' (Shipyard Marine Industrial Services), well known as '''SIMA''' or '''SIMA PERU S.A.''', is a Peruvian [[shipyard]] that operates as a state owned company established under private law in 1950 pursuing the activities of the former Naval Factory founded in 1845, and continually extending its operational capacity, first to the shipbuilding which SIMA pioneered in [[South America]] and then to the greatest metalworking structures manufacture, contributing to the defense and socio-economic development of Peru. The SIMA principally serve the [[Navy of Peru]] as well as domestic and foreign private clients through a wide range of products.{{cite news|url=http://www.sima.com.pe/ace_empresa_eng.asp|title=SIMA, the company|publisher=sima.com.pe|date=August 14, 2015}} ==History== On May 22, 1845 during the first government of President [[Ramón Castilla]], the State Factory in the city of [[Callao]] was established. Then named Naval Factory, this facility would become a leading establishment of its kind in South America. Such decision to establish this factory was due to the fact that Peru had taken steps to acquire the steamship "Rimac", first steam warship of the national navy at that time in the year of 1844, making it necessary to have an establishment where maintenance and repair could be provided.{{cite news|url=http://www.sima.com.pe/ace_historia_eng.asp|title=History´s SIMA|publisher=sima.com.pe|date=August 14, 2015}} [[File:BAP Humboldt.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[B.I.C. Humboldt]], Peruvian oceanographic research vessel built in 1978 by SIMA.]] On August 7, 1861 by orders of the President of the Republic, General Juan Antonio Pezet, the Naval Factory was entirely taken over by the Navy, arranging the creation of the Naval Factory Superintendence, thus achieving performance optimization. Years later the Naval Factory made history participating in the construction of the first South American armored ship monitor "Victoria" and the conversion of steamship "Loa" into an armored vehicle; installing machinery, artillery and hull armor. Both ships were part of the national fleet that confronted the Spanish fleet during the naval [[Battle of Callao]] in 1866. During the [[War of the Pacific|Pacific War]] the Naval Factory was actively engaged in the national efforts to confront the military conflict meeting the requirements of both the Navy and the Army. Unfortunately, at the end of the war, its facilities were destroyed after heroic efforts of men to serve even under the most difficult circumstances, thereby constituting the oldest record of what SIMA is today. In the post war years, few of the ships possessed by the Navy were repaired in the state-owned floating dock of the "Compañía Peruana de Vapores y Dique del Callao" until 1930, date on winch it sank, forcing the Navy to send its ships to the Panama Canal zone, among other foreign shipyards. [[File:BAP Mariategui Panamax 2004.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[BAP Mariátegui (FM-54)|BAP Mariátegui]], frigate built in 1984 by SIMA.]] In a situation of dependence on foreign shipyards, the Navy of Peru took up again naval repair activities to serve their small-sized vessels, creating the Naval Station of San Lorenzo in 1921. In 1925, with the arrival of submarines Type "R", the Naval Station of San Lorenzo was modernized installing machinery at the workshops and a modern shipyard with capacity of 800 tns bollard pull, inaugurated with the entry of torpedo-boat destroyer "Rodriguez". On February 14, 1950 during the government of [[Manuel A. Odría]], Servicios Industriales de la Marina (Marine Industrial Services) known as SIMA was created over the base of the Industrial Department of the Navy Dockyard, assigning the dry dock administration and workshops in order to serve the Peruvian Navy, the National Merchant Marine and private entities successfully. With creation of SIMA under administration of the Navy, the decision to get into the shipbuilding activity was made. Preparation of the shipyard for that purpose began. Berth number one, mould-loft, shipbuilding workshop among others were constructed. On March, 25th 1999 Law N° 27073 was enacted, regulating activities of the company within the scope of the defense sector and paying particular attention to the Navy of Peru as well as individuals customers in order to generate profits to self-finance its own development and fulfill its role in society. ==Ships built== [[File:BAP Unión arribando al Callao.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[BAP Unión (BEV-161)|BAP Unión]], sail training ship built in 2014 by SIMA.]] Ships built at the SIMA yard include: * BAP ''Zorritos'', [[Oil tanker]], {{liy|1960}} * [[B.I.C. Humboldt|BIC ''Humboldt'']], [[Oceanographic research ship]], {{liy|1978}} * {{ship|BAP|Montero|FM-53}}, [[guided missile frigate]], {{liy|1982}} * {{ship|BAP|Mariátegui|FM-54}}, [[guided missile frigate]], {{liy|1984}} * {{ship|BAP|Unión|BEV-161}}, [[Sail training]] ship {{liy|2014}} * two balsawood rafts, for the [[Kon-Tiki2]] Expedition, 2015 *{{ship|BAP|Rio Pativilca|PM-204}}, [[patrol boat]], {{liy|2016}}{{cite web|title=Bautizo de las patrulleras BAP Rio Pativilca y BAP Rio Cañete de la Marina de Guerra del Peru|url=http://www.defensa.com/frontend/defensa/noticia.php?id_noticia=18199&id_seccion=336}} * {{ship|BAP|Rio Cañete|PM-205}}, [[patrol boat]], {{liy|2016}} * {{ship|BAP|Rio Piura|PM-206}}, [[patrol boat]], {{liy|2017}}{{cite web|title= 22/7/2016 Las adquisiciones de Defensa que han recuperado la capacidad operativa y de respuesta de las Fuerzas Armadas del Perú |url= https://www.mindef.gob.pe/informacion/documentos/adquisiciones_defensa.pdf}} * {{ship|BAP|Rio Quilca|PM-207}}, [[patrol boat]], {{liy|2017}}{{cite web|title= 9/12/2016 Avances en la construccion de las patrulleras BAP Rio Piura y BAP Rio Quilca |url=http://www.defensa.com/frontend/defensa/avances-construccion-patrulleras-bap-rio-piura-bap-rio-quilca-vn19446-vst336}} * {{ship|BAP|Pisco|AMP-156}}, multipurpose ship, {{liy|2017}} Its SIMA-CEFAR ("Servicios Industriales de la Marina-Centro de Fabricacion de Armas") unit builds the [[MGP-84]] [[submachine gun]].{{cite news|url=http://www.janes.com/extract/idr95/idr00598.html|title=PERU'S MGP-84 MINI TOWARDS A MORE COMPACT SUB-MACHINEGUN|date=Apr 1, 1995|work=Jane's International Defence Review|accessdate=2008-09-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.sima.com.pe/ Official Website] {{Peruvian Armed Forces}} '''SML Isuzu Limited''' (SMLI) is a commercial vehicle manufacturer established in 1983. SMLI produces and sells buses, ambulances and customized vehicles. [[Sumitomo Corporation]] and [[Isuzu Motors]] hold a 44% and 15% stake of the company respectively.
==History== The company was incorporated in July 1983 with the name of Swaraj Vehicles Limited.
===1984=== Joint venture and technical assistance agreement concluded between Punjab Tractor Ltd., [[Mazda Motor Corporation]] and [[Sumitomo Corporation]]. SVL renamed Swaraj Mazda Ltd.
===1985=== Project set up with a capacity of 5000 [[light commercial vehicles]] (LCVs) at capital outlay of Rs. 200 million. Equity of Rs. 105 million was subscribed by: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Company !! Percentage in Equity !! Rs. in Crores |- | Punjab Tractors Ltd. || 29.0% || 3.04 |- | Mazda Motor Corp. Japan || 15.6% || 1.64 |- | Sumitomo Corp. Japan || 10.4% || 1.09 |- | Public || 45.0% || 4.73 |} Trial production and test marketing of [[Swaraj Mazda]] truck WT-48, WT-49, WT-50 LCV commence. The development of the vendor base undertaken as per approved by the government of [[India]].
===1986=== Commercial operations begin.
===1987=== Introduction of indigenously developed bus.
===1989=== In-house tooling for local production of chassis long member.
===1990=== In-house developed Second Truck Model (Swaraj Mazda Super) launched.
===1991=== Transmission components indigenized.
===1992=== Commencement of Truck supplies to MOD. 500 vehicles supplied to Defence.
===1993=== Third Truck Model (Swaraj Mazda Premium) launched.
===1994=== Declared a Sick Company under SICA (due to [[Rupee]] devaluation of 1991–93).
===1995=== BIFR approves Rehabilitation Scheme.
===1996=== 4-Wheel Drive Truck developed.
===1997=== Company ceases to be a Sick Industrial Company on the basis of positive net worth 4 years ahead of BIFR Scheme projections.
===1998=== Completely wiped off of accumulated losses.
===1999=== Bharat Stage-I Emission Norms complied.
===2000=== Maiden Dividend declared at 10%.Technical Assistance Agreement with Mazda extended up to October 2004.
===2001=== Cumulative sales crossed 50,000 vehicles. 4 Wheel Drive Ambulance launched in March. Economy Truck 'SARTAJ' launched in August. CNG Bus for NCR Delhi launched in October.Bharat Stage-II Emission Norms complied.
===2002=== Profit Before Tax for FY 2002 crosses Rs. 100 Million mark.Dividend raised to 25%.
===2003=== Profit Before Tax for FY-2003 grows 115% to Rs. 225 Million. Dividend enhanced to 45%.
===2004=== Profit Before Tax for FY-2004 grows 44% to Rs. 324 Million. Dividend enhanced to 70%.
===2005=== Cumulative sales crossed 86,000 vehicles. Bharat Stage-III emission norms complied (both diesel & CNG). Dividend enhanced to 75%. Punjab Tractors offloads 15% of equity stake in favor of Sumitomo Corporation, Japan in June.Mazda Motor Corporation offloads 15% of equity holding in favor of Sumitomo Corporation, Japan in August.
===2006=== Permission from Government for new manufacturing facilities at existing site obtained in January. Dividend rate lowered to 55% due profit and declined the Technical Assistance Agreement with Isuzu Motors signed in June. Aggregate vehicles sale crosses {{formatnum:100000}} in August. Construction of Buildings for vehicle expansion and new Bus Body Plant taken up in August.
===2007=== Dividend rate maintained at 55%.Trial Production of Isuzu Bus LT134 taken up in July.
===2008=== Dividend rate maintained at 55%. Highest-ever profit in the history of the Company.Launch of Ultra Luxury Buses in July.
===2009=== Sumitomo raised its stake in the Company to 53.5% by buying entire equity holding of Punjab Tractors Ltd. in the Company in January.

'''South Moravian Innovation Centre''' (SIC) is an association of companies in [[Brno]], [[Czech republic]] that connects universities and research institutions with companies.
== History == [[File:Biotechnologický inkubátor JIC INBIT.jpg|thumb|380x380px|One of the SIC buildings: biotechnology incubator SIC INBIT in university campus in Brno Bohunice]] SIC was founded in 2003. Notable members include [[South Moravia]]n region, city of Brno, [[Masaryk University]], [[Brno University of Technology]], [[Mendel University]] and [[University of Veterinary and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Brno|University of Veterinary and Pharmaceutical Sciences]].
== Activities == SIC manages two technology incubators at Brno University of Technology and a biotechnological incubator in the university campus in Brno-Bohunice.
Companies which started in SIC include [[Y Soft Corporation|Y Soft]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hyperstudent.cz/vaclav-muchna-brnensky-gates.php |title=Václav Muchna – brněnský Gates |publisher=HyperStudent.cz |language=Czech |date=January 26, 2010 |accessdate=2014-05-15}} {{cz icon}}</ref> Safetica Technologies, [[Flowmon Networks]], Sewio, [[Kiwi.com]] and FlowUp.
== Awards == SIC won 3rd place in national round of The Best Incubator Award 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/ekonomika/162091-jihomoravske-inovacni-centrum-se-radi-mezi-nejlepsi-na-svete/ |title=Jihomoravské inovační centrum se řadí mezi nejlepší na světě — Ekonomika — ČT24 — Česká televize |publisher=Ceskatelevize.cz |language=Czech |date=2012-01-26 |accessdate=2014-05-15}} {{cz icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kr-jihomoravsky.cz/Default.aspx?ID=178630&TypeID=2 |title=Portál Jihomoravského kraje |publisher=Kr-jihomoravsky.cz |language=Czech |date= |accessdate=2014-05-15}} {{cz icon}}</ref>

{{Expand Spanish|Burbuja inmobiliaria en España|date=April 2011}} [[File:vivienda n jun2009.png|thumb|300px|Evolution of the price of square meter in Spain, in euros]] [[File:Stages of a bubble.png|thumb|300px|Stages of a speculative bubble]] The '''Spanish property bubble''' is the collapsed overshooting part of a long-term price increase of Spanish [[real estate]] prices. This long-term price increase has happened in various stages from 1985 up to 2008.<ref>La burbuja inmobiliario-financiera en la coyuntura económica reciente (1985-1995). {{ISBN|978-84-323-0913-7}}.</ref><ref> {{cite web | last = Azumendi | first = Eduardo | title = La otra burbuja inmobiliaria | work = [[El País]] | publisher = Grupo Prisa | language = Spanish | date = 29 June 2009 | url = http://www.elpais.com/articulo/pais/vasco/burbuja/inmobiliaria/elpepiesppvs/20090629elpvas_1/Tes | accessdate = 3 November 2013}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal | last1 = Rullan | first1 = Onofre | last2 = Artigues | first2 = Antoni A. | title = Estrategias para combatir el encarecimiento de la vivienda en España. ¿Construir más o intervenir en el parque existente? | journal = REVISTA ELECTRÓNICA DE GEOGRAFÍA Y CIENCIAS SOCIALES | volume = XI | issue = 245 | pages = 28 | publisher = [[Universidad de Barcelona]] | date = 1 August 2008 | language = Spanish | url = http://www.ub.edu/geocrit/sn/sn-24528.htm | issn = 1138-9788 | accessdate = 3 November 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.invertia.com/noticias/articulo-final.asp?idNoticia=2413254 Mapa de la sobrevaloración de la vivienda en España] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928153657/http://www.invertia.com/noticias/articulo-final.asp?idNoticia=2413254 |date=2011-09-28 }} - [[Invertia]]</ref><ref>[http://www.ecosbolsa.com/index.php/inmobiliaria/44-sector-inmobiliario/1180-precios-historicos-vivienda-espana.html Precios históricos vivienda España] - [[Ecobolsa]]</ref><ref>[http://www.libertaddigital.com/economia/la-depresion-industrial-augura-el-fin-de-la-burbuja-en-el-sector-servicios-1276409353/ La depresión industrial augura el fin de la burbuja en el sector servicios] - [[Libertad Digital]]</ref><ref>[http://www.elimparcial.es/contenido/5750.html La burbuja inmobiliaria ha inflado el precio de las viviendas un 40 por ciento] - [[El Imparcial]]</ref><ref>[http://www.juandemariana.org/estudio/1898/precios/vivienda/burbuja/inmobiliaria/espana/ Los precios de la vivienda y la burbuja inmobiliaria en España] - [[Instituto Juan de Mariana]]</ref><ref>[http://www.consumer.es/web/es/economia_domestica/2003/01/04/55974.php En los últimos 17 años el precio de la vivienda en España se ha multiplicado por cinco] - [[Consumer]]</ref> The housing bubble can be clearly divided in three periods: 1985–1991, in which the price nearly tripled; 1992–1996, in which the price remained somewhat stable; and 1996–2008, in which prices grew astonishingly again. Coinciding with the [[financial crisis of 2007–08]], prices began to fall. In 2013, Raj Badiani, an economist at IHS Global Insight in London, estimated that the value of residential real estate has dropped more than 30 percent since 2007 and that house prices would fall at least 50 percent from the peak by 2015.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-19/spanish-banks-cut-developers-as-zombies-dying-mortgages.html | work=Bloomberg | first1=Sharon | last1=Smyth | first2=Rob | last2=Urban | title=Spanish Banks Cut Developers as Zombies Dying: Mortgages | date=2013-03-20}}</ref> According to Alcidi and Gros note,<ref>http://www.voxeu.org/article/whats-wrong-spain</ref> “If construction were to continue at the still relatively high rate of today, the process of absorption of the bubble would take more than 30 years.”
== Dynamics == House ownership in Spain is above 80%. The desire to own one's own home was encouraged by governments in the 1960s and '70s, and has thus become part of the Spanish psyche. In addition, tax regulation encourages ownership: 15% of mortgage payments are deductible from personal income taxes. Further, the oldest apartments are controlled by non-inflation-adjusted rent-controls<ref> {{cite web | last = Expósito | first = Antonio A. | title = Todo lo que tienes que saber sobre los alquileres de renta antigua | work = jublio.es | publisher = Júbilo Comunicación, S.L. | date = 4 November 2005 | language = Spanish | url = http://www.jubilo.es/asp/pagina.asp?IDPagina=3360 | accessdate = 3 November 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011230256/http://jubilo.es/asp/pagina.asp?IDPagina=3360 | archivedate = 11 October 2007}}</ref> and eviction is slow, thereby discouraging renting. Banks offered 40-year and, more recently, 50-year [[mortgage loan|mortgage]]s.
As feared, when the [[Economic bubble|speculative bubble]] popped, Spain became one of the worst affected countries. According to [[eurostat]], over the June 2007-June 2008 period, Spain has been the European country with the sharpest plunge in construction rates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elpais.com/elpaismedia/ultimahora/media/200808/20/espana/20080820elpepunac_1_Pes_PDF.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320111018/http://www.elpais.com/elpaismedia/ultimahora/media/200808/20/espana/20080820elpepunac_1_Pes_PDF.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-20 |df= }}</ref> In 2008, new constructions came virtually to a halt, but prices were initially relatively stable with sellers reluctant to offer large discounts. The national average price as of late 2008 was 2,095 euros/m2<ref>[http://www.cotizalia.com/cache/2008/08/28/noticias_50_900000_viviendas_construidas_inmobiliario_estan.html]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalpropertyguide.com/Europe/Spain |title=Recent history of the Spanish residential property market |publisher=Global Property Guide}}</ref> Actual sales over the July 2007-June 2008 period were down an average 25.3% (with the lion's share of the loss arguably happening in the 2008 tract of this period). Some regions have been more affected than others ([[Catalonia]] was ahead in this regard with a 42.2% sales plunge while sparsely populated regions like [[Extremadura]] were down a mere 1.7% over the same period).<ref>[http://www.lavanguardia.es/lv24h/20080923/53544998493.html]</ref>
Unlike much of the United States, Spain does not recognize mortgage loans as [[nonrecourse debt]]. Since property prices dropped enough for most foreclosures to only account for 60% of the loan, those evicted have large debts for property they no longer own.<ref> {{cite news | last = Hogan | first = Caelainn | title = Spanish property bubble fallout continues with evictions, debt and fear of homelessness | work = The Irish Times | date = 14 November 2011 | url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/1114/1224307526614.html | accessdate = 3 November 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111114231718/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/1114/1224307526614.html | archivedate = 14 November 2011}}</ref>
== Figures ==
=== Prices and number of houses built === According to the reports of the [[Bank of Spain]], between 1976 and 2003, the price of housing in Spain has doubled in real terms, which means, in nominal terms, a multiplication by 16. In the period of 1997—2006, the price of housing in Spain had risen about 150% in nominal terms, equivalent to 100% growth in real terms. It is stated that from 2000 to 2009, 5 million new housing units had been added to the existing stock of 20 million.<ref>Bardhan, A., Edelstein, R. & Kroll, C. (2011), [https://books.google.com/books?id=VVEvNclICcgC&dq=Bardhan,+A.,+Edelstein,+R.+%26+Kroll,+C.+2011,+&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s "The Financial Crisis and Housing Markets Worldwide"] in ''Global Housing Market: Crises, Policies, and Institutions''</ref> In 2008, the real estate market started to drop fast, and house prices decreased dramatically by 8% in that year.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/12725415 "Spain's Property Crash: Builders' Nightmare"], 2008, ''The Economist''</ref> In the period of 2007-2013, Spanish house prices had fallen by 37%.<ref>Karaian, J. 2013, [http://qz.com/124088/spanish-real-estate-has-lost-more-than-a-third-of-its-value-but-its-still-overvalued ''The Pain in Spain''], Quartz</ref> Each year almost a million homes were built in Spain, more than in Germany, France, and England altogether.<ref>[http://topspanishhomes.com/blogs/some-facts-about-spanish-housing-bubble]</ref>
=== Real estate debt === [[Image:Spanishdebt.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The housing bubble was fed by the credit to private sector (individuals and developers), which led to a significant increase in private debt (blue) stopped with the international financial crisis, ending the speculative process.]] One of the main effects of this situation is the growth of [[household debt]]. Since usually the purchase of housing, whether to live or to invest, is made from mortgage loans, the price increase implies an increase in debt. The indebtedness of the Spanish tripled in less than ten years. In 1986, debt represented 34% of disposable income, in 1997 it rose to 52%, and in 2005 it came to 105%. In 2006, a quarter of the population was indebted with maturities of more than 15 years.<ref>[http://www.nodo50.org/ramonfd/tsunami_urbanizador.pdf "El tsunami urbanizador"], pág 24 y sig.</ref> From 1990 to 2004, the average length of mortgages increased from 12 to 25 years.<ref>[http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=05MADRID1088&q=spain Spain's Booming Housing Market And The Uncertain Future]</ref> The Bank of Spain reported that household savings in 2006 has been overwhelmed by debt.<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/mundodinero/2007/08/15/economia/1187164139.html Diario El Mundo: El pago de deudas se 'comió' en 2006 todo el nuevo ahorro de las familias españolas.]</ref>
In fact, the Bank of Spain has warned each year about the high indebtedness of Spanish households,<ref>[http://www.consumer.es/web/es/economia_domestica/2003/05/15/61428.php Año 2003: el Banco de España alerta...], [http://www.cincodias.com/articulo/empresas/Banco/Espana/alerta/subida/riesgo/hipotecario/cdscdi/20041112cdscdiemp_41/Tes/ Año 2004: el Banco de España alerta...], [http://www.finanzas.com/id.9066477/noticias/noticia.htm "Año 2006: el Banco de España alerta..."]</ref> which according to the institution was unsustainable. The private debt stood at 832.289 billion euros at the end of 2006, an increase of 18.53% year-on-year, and reached 1 trillion euros by the end of 2010.<ref>[http://www.elperiodicodearagon.com/noticias/noticia.asp?pkid=316007 El Periódico de Aragón.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911022430/http://www.elperiodicodearagon.com/noticias/noticia.asp?pkid=316007 |date=2010-09-11 }}</ref> The Bank of Spain also warned on the excessive indebtedness of the construction industry.<ref>[http://www.elconfidencial.com/economia/noticia.asp?id=8822 "Alerta del Banco de España a las contructoras"], '' El Confidencial''</ref>
President of the Chambers of Commerce of Spain, Javier Gómez Navarro, said at an event organized by the Association of Financial Journalists, entities "never recover" 30% of the debt owed to the housing sector. According to the Bank of Spain, this debt amounted to 325,000 million euros as of December 2009 was 96.824 million in bad loans.<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/articulo/economia/deuda/ladrillo/castigara/banca/Camaras/Comercio/elpepueco/20100310elpepieco_8/Tes "La deuda del ladrillo castigará a la banca, según las Cámaras de Comercio"], ''El País'', March 10, 2010</ref> The president of the Chambers regretted that the Spanish financial system did not admit the impact of the crisis on their assets, as well as the Bank of Spain, which affirmed that it was the responsibility of the whole financial sector: "In Spain, it was never wanted to recognize that the financial system was not in good shape, as this would have forced the banking sector to start re-capitalising policies. The goal of the state's policy has so far been to gain time, to start a mild bank recapitalisation, but time is now running out".<ref>[http://www.intereconomia.com/noticias-negocios/finanzas-personales/politica-economica/gomez-navarro-alerta-que-los-bancos-pueden- "Gómez Navarro cree que los bancos pueden 'quedarse' con el dinero del ICO"] ''Intereconomía''</ref>
According to R.R. de Acuna & Asociados, a real-estate consulting firm, more than half of the country’s 67,000 developers can be categorized as “zombies”, having liabilities that exceed their assets and only enough income to repay the interest on their loans.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-19/spanish-banks-cut-developers-as-zombies-dying-mortgages.html | work=Bloomberg | first1 =Sharon | last1=Smyth | first2=Rob | last2=Urban | title= Spanish Banks Cut Developers as Zombies Dying: Mortgages | date=2013-03-20}}</ref> According to the Bank of Spain, the rate of household doubtful loans among the total amount of credit increased from 0.8% in 2005 to 6.2% in 2011.<ref>http://www.craig.csufresno.edu/International_Programs/JC/IJB/Volumes/Volume%2017/V174-2.pdf</ref>
== See also == * [[Great Recession in Spain]] * [[Savings bank (Spain)]] * [[Unemployment in Spain]]

'''Stephen L. Vargo, Ph.D''' is a Shidler Distinguished Professor and Professor of Marketing at the [[University of Hawai’i]] at Manoa. He has an MS degree in social psychology and a Ph.D. in Marketing. He has held visiting positions at the [[University of Maryland]], College Park the [[University of California]], Riverside, and the [[University of Auckland]]. Prior to entering academics, he had a career in entrepreneurial business and has consulted for a variety of major national, regional, and local corporations and governmental agencies.
==Research== Professor Vargo’s primary areas of research are marketing theory and thought, [[service dominant logic (marketing)]], and consumers’ evaluative reference scales. He has had articles published in the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]'', the ''[[Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science]]'', the ''[[Journal of Service Research]]'', the ''Journal of Retailing'', the ''Journal of Macromarketing'', and other major marketing journals and books, including, ''The Service Dominant Logic of Marketing: Dialog, Debate, and Directions'', which he co-edited.
==Editorial Positions== Professor Vargo currently serves on the editorial review boards of the ''Journal of Marketing'', the ''Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science'', ''Journal of Service Research'', the ''Australasian Marketing Journal'', and the ''Journal of Service Management and Service Science''. He has also served as co-editor of a special issue of the ''Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science'', as well as editor of special issues in other leading journals such as ''European Journal of Marketing'' and ''Marketing Theory''.
==Awards== Professor Vargo has been awarded the Best Article of the Year Award by the Australia and New Zealand Marketing Academy, the Harold H. Maynard Award by the [[American Marketing Association]] for ‘significant contribution to marketing theory and thought’ and the Sheth Foundation Award for ‘long-term contribution to the field of marketing’. His 2004 article with [[Robert Lusch]] in the [[Journal of Marketing]], “Evolving to a New Dominant Logic for Marketing,” is the most-cited marketing article published in the last 10 years.
== External links == * [http://www.shidler.hawaii.edu/sites/shidler.hawaii.edu/files/users/user-137/cv_vargo.pdf CV]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} * [http://www.shidler.hawaii.edu/directory/stephen-vargo/mkt University of Hawaii at Manoa, Stephen Vargo] * [http://www.sdlogic.net Service-Dominant Logic Website] * [http://www.sdlogic.net/publications.html Selected Publications on Service-Dominant Logic]
==References== * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2004) [http://dret.net/lectures/ssme-spring07/VargoReading-Recommended.pdf ‘Evolving to a New Dominant Logic for Marketing’], ''Journal of Marketing'' 68 (January): 1 – 17. * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2008) “Service-Dominant Logic: Continuing the Evolution,” Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science 36, 1-10. * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2011) “It's all B2B…and beyond: Toward a systems perspective of the market,” Industrial Marketing Management 40, 181-187.

Jendral Gatot Subroto kav. 52, [[Jakarta]], Indonesia |key_people = [[Ririek Adriansyah]] (CEO) |industry = Telecommunication |products = kartuHalo, simPATI, Kartu As, Flash, and LOOP |parent = PT [[Telkom Indonesia]] Tbk |owners = [[Telkom Indonesia|PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia Tbk]] (65.0%){{cite web|url=http://www.telkomsel.com/media/upload/annualreport/AR_TSEL2014.pdf |format=PDF |title=Continuing to Win in the Digital Era |website=Telkomsel.com |accessdate=2017-04-26}}
[[Singapore Telecommunications Limited]] via its wholly owned subsidiary Singapore Telecom Mobile Pte. Ltd. (35.0%){{cite web |url=http://www.airtel.in/wps/wcm/connect/about+bharti+airtel/Bharti+Airtel/Investor+Relations/Shares/PG_Shares?countrytabs=1 |title=Shareholding Pattern | Bharti Airtel |website=Airtel.in |date= |accessdate=28 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524043538/http://www.airtel.in/wps/wcm/connect/about%2Bbharti%2Bairtel/Bharti%2BAirtel/Investor%2BRelations/Shares/PG_Shares?countrytabs=1 |archivedate=24 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.airtel.in/wps/wcm/connect/eaa4f38049da295db5a6f7d8801acd16/Shareholding_pattern_December_31_2011.pdf?MOD=AJPERES|title=Shareholding Pattern as of Dec 2011| Bharti Airtel|website=Airtel.in|date=|accessdate=28 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826163655/http://www.airtel.in/wps/wcm/connect/eaa4f38049da295db5a6f7d8801acd16/Shareholding_pattern_December_31_2011.pdf?MOD=AJPERES|archivedate=26 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} |homepage = {{Official website|http://www.telkomsel.com/|}} }} [[File:Telkomsel HQ.jpg|thumb|200px|Telkomsel Telecommunication Center (TTC) Building in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia]] '''PT Telekomunikasi Selular''', trading as '''Telkomsel''', is an [[Indonesia|Indonesian]] wireless network provider founded in 1995 and is a subsidiary of [[Telkom Indonesia]]. It is headquartered in [[South Jakarta]]. Telkomsel is the largest wireless carrier in the country with 172 million customers as of 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://industri.kontan.co.id/news/jumlah-pelanggan-seluler-menyusut|title=Jumlah pelanggan seluler menyusut|last=Mediatama|first=Grahanusa|date=2018-04-24|work=kontan.co.id|access-date=2018-07-25|language=id}} The company Operates their [[GSM]] network on the 900–1800 MHz frequency range, as well as [[3G]] and [[4G]] services on other frequencies. Telkomsel operates a variety of sim card brands, chief among them are simPATI and kartuHALO. These brands differ on their payment model (pre-paid vs. post-paid) as well as pricing. As of 31 March 2015, Telkomsel has 46% of the Indonesian wireless service market share.{{cite web|url=http://info.singtel.com/sites/default/files/invrel_areports/Singtel_AR2014_b.pdf |format=PDF |title=Annual Report 2014 |website=Info.singtel.com |accessdate=2017-04-26}} ==History== Telkomsel was incorporated on 26 May 1995 in Jakarta, Indonesia. It is majority owned by Telkom Indonesia with 65% of the shares, with [[Singtel|Singapore Telecommunications Limited]] owning the minority 35%.{{cite web| url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1186063l| title=Telkomsel on BusinessWeek|website=Investing.businessweek.com| accessdate=23 July 2010}} In November 1997, Telkomsel became the first wireless carrier in Asia to introduce rechargeable GSM pre-paid services. In September 2006, Telkomsel became the first carrier in the country to launch a 3G service. On 20 March 2009, Telkomsel and [[Apple Inc.|Apple South Asia Pte. Ltd.]] launched the [[iPhone 3G]] in Indonesia with customised price plans for all of Telkomsel's customers.{{cite web |url=http://www.beritateknologi.com/telkomsel-segera-meluncurkan-iphone-3g-resmi-masuk-indonesia/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217032322/http://www.beritateknologi.com/telkomsel-segera-meluncurkan-iphone-3g-resmi-masuk-indonesia |archivedate=17 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Three years later, Telkomsel had acquired more than 100 million active customers.{{cite web|url=http://www.indonesia-investments.com/business/indonesian-companies/telekomunikasi-indonesia/item201|title=Telekomunikasi Indonesia – Telkom – Indonesia Investments|website=Indonesia-investments.com|accessdate=26 April 2017}} In April 2017, the company website was hacked, and a message protesting about high charges and unnecessary extra services was posted. There was widespread support for the hacker on social media.{{cite web | title = Telkomsel Hacked, Customers Vent Frustration Over Internet Price | author1 = Dion Bisara |author2 = Herman | publisher = [[The Jakarta Globe]] | date = 18 April 2017 | url = http://jakartaglobe.id/business/telkomsel-hacked-customers-vent-frustation-internet-price/ | access-date = 15 May 2017}} ===Slogans=== * ''Telkomsel. So Close, So Real'' (Indonesian: Begitu Dekat, Begitu Nyata, 1995–2005){{citation needed|date=July 2014}} * ''Leading in Service'' (2008, 13th anniversary) * ''Widest Network, Best Quality'' (Indonesian: Jangkauan Luas, Kualitas Terbaik, 2008–present) * ''Telkomsel Paling Indonesia'' (2010–present) * ''Jangkauan Terluas Tercepat'' (2015–present) * ''14 Tahun Telkomsel Untuk Indonesia'' (2009, 14th anniversary, English: 14th Anniversary Telkomsel for Indonesia) * ''15 Tahun Telkomsel Inovasi Untuk Negeri'' (2010, 15th anniversary, English: Innovation for the nation) * ''16 Tahun Telkomsel 100 Juta pelanggan'' (2011, 16th anniversary, English: 100 million customers) * ''17 Tahun Telkomsel Muda, Beda, Paling Indonesia'' (2012, 17th anniversary, English: Young, Different, More Indonesia) * ''18 Tahun Telkomsel Muda, Berbagi, Paling Indonesia'' (2013, 18th anniversary, English: Young, Sharing, More Indonesia) * ''19 Tahun Telkomsel For More Colorful Future'' (2014, 19th anniversary) * ''20 Tahun Telkomsel Kreasi Untuk Indonesia'' (2015, 20th anniversary, English: Creation for Indonesia) * ''21 Tahun Telkomsel Bikin Keren Indonesia'' (2016, 21st anniversary, English: Make Indonesia Cooler) * ''22 Tahun Telkomsel Memajukan Negeri'' (2017, 22nd anniversary, English: Advancing the Nation) == Products and services == === Telkomsel products === * [[:id:KartuHalo|kartuHalo]] * [[:id:SimPATI|simPATI]] * [[:id:Kartu_As|Kartu As]] * [[:id:Kartu_As_Flexi|Kartu As Flexi]] is a combination of the previous prepaid operators, Flexi and all Flexi prepaid customers are transferred to this card. * [[:id:KartuHalo_Flexi|kartuHalo Flexi]] is a combination of the previous prepaid operators, Flexi and all Flexi prepaid customers are transferred to this card. * [[:id:Telkomsel_Flash|Telkomsel Flash]] * [[:id:Kartu_Facebook|Kartu Facebook]] * [[:id:SimPATI_LOOP|simPATI LOOP]] * [[:id:Kartu_LOOP|Kartu LOOP]] === Telkomsel services === ==== Telkomsel Poin ==== The TELKOMSELPOIN program is a customer loyalty program that is intended for all TELKOMSEL customers. ==== ''GraPARI'' ==== '''''GraPARI''''' is an acronym for ''Graha Pari Sraya'' (Service Office Building in [[English language|English]]) which is used as a Telkomsel customer service center. The name comes from the [[Sanskrit Language|Sanskrit language]] given by Sri Sultan Hamengkubuwono X as a sign of appreciation for the inauguration of the Telkomsel service office in Yogyakarta. Since then, all Telkomsel customer service centers have been established under the name ''GraPARI'' Telkomsel. === Former service === ==== HSPA ==== Starting in September 2009, Telkomsel added HSPA + (High-Speed Packet Access) services with access speeds of up to 21 Mbps which are planned to be implemented in 24 cities in Indonesia until the end of 2010. ==Network coverage== As of 2018, Telkomsel has 160.705 [[Base transceiver station|Base Transceiver Stations]] (BTS) with 68.7% being 3G/4G capable.{{Cite news|url=https://pasarmodal.inilah.com/read/detail/2452486/pelanggan-telkomsel-membludak-jumlah-bts-digenjot|title=Pelanggan Telkomsel Membludak, Jumlah BTS Digenjot|last=Center|first=PT. Indonesia News|work=inilahcom|access-date=2018-07-25|language=en}} Telkomsel currently has one of the widest [[network coverage]] in Indonesia, providing service in over 97% of Indonesia's territories. This makes it the only operator in Indonesia that has coverage in all of the country's [[Provinces of Indonesia|provinces]] and regencies.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} The network uses [[GSM]] Dual Band (900 & 1800), [[GPRS]], [[EDGE]], [[3G]], and [[4G]] technologies. The company has 323 international roaming partners in 170 countries (September 2008). In addition, Telkomsel has worked with network carriers in neighboring countries to offer the co-branded ''simPATI Kangen'' product for Indonesians living abroad. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Jakarta|Indonesia}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.telkomsel.com/}} {{Telkom Indonesia}} {{Indonesia mobile phone companies}} {{Bridge Alliance}} [[Category:Mobile phone companies of Indonesia]] [[Category:Companies established in 1995]] [[Category:Indonesian brands]]

{{UKtaxation}} The '''Windfall Tax''' was a [[tax]] on what were claimed to be "the excess [[Profit (accounting)|profits]] of the privatised [[Public utility|utilities]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.treasury.gov.uk/pub/html/budget97/ir1.html |title=1997 Budget |publisher=HM Treasury |accessdate=31 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928040614/http://archive.treasury.gov.uk/pub/html/budget97/ir1.html |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }}</ref> and was introduced by the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government of [[Tony Blair]] in 1997. It followed from their manifesto commitment made during the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]] campaign to impose a "windfall levy" on the privatised utilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsresources.net/area/uk/man/lab97.htm|title=New Labour, because Britain deserves better|publisher=Political Science Resources|accessdate= 31 July 2008}}</ref> The tax came after 18 years of [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government, which had seen the privatization of many state-owned assets, at prices which many considered too low. It aimed to "put right the bad deal which customers and taxpayers got from the privatisation of the utilities".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/cm199798/cmhansrd/vo970710/text/70710w22.htm|title=House of Commons Hansard Written Answers for 10 Jul 1997 (pt 22)|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=31 July 2008}}</ref> The tax produced an estimated one off income to the government of £5 billion, which was used to fund the [[New Deal (UK)|New Deal]], a welfare-to-work program that sought to tackle long-term unemployment, as well as providing capital investment for schools and the [[University for Industry]] (Learndirect).
== The tax ==
The tax was calculated by means of a 9 times [[P/E ratio]], whereby the average post-tax profit in the four years after privatization was multiplied by 9 to give the value for the purposes of the tax. The difference between this value and the total market capitalisation based on the company's flotation price was subject to a 23% "windfall tax". The tax was charged to the company and was payable in two instalments on 1 December 1997 and 1 December 1998.
The companies affected were those privatized by the [[Telecommunications Act 1984]], the Airports Act 1986, the Gas Act 1986, the Water Act 1989, the Electricity Act 1989 (and the Electricity (Northern Ireland) Order 1992) and the Railways Act 1993. The firms affected were [[BAA Limited|BAA]], [[British Energy]], [[British Gas plc|British Gas]] (now BG plc and Centrica), [[British Telecom]], National Power, [[Northern Ireland Electricity]], [[Powergen]], [[Scottish Hydro]], [[Scottish Power]] and [[Railtrack]], the regional electricity companies and the privatized water and sewerage companies (including such companies now forming part of Hyder, [[United Utilities]] and Scottish Power).
Since 1997, no further windfall taxes have been levied in the UK. However, calls have been made for new windfall taxes. The ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported in January 2008 that the government was considering ways of maximising returns to the treasury from the sale of the troubled [[Northern Rock]] bank, which could include a windfall tax or the government taking an equity stake.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto012020081805161152&page=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929154905/http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto012020081805161152&page=2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-09-29|work=Financial Times}}</ref> In the event, the bank was not sold on to private investors, but instead came under UK government ownership.
== Windfall tax on energy companies ==
Calls were made for a windfall tax on energy companies during the summer of 2008 in the wake of energy price rises and the environmental record of the oil and gas industry.<ref>{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/jul/31/bggroupbusiness.utilities|title=British Gas adds fuel to windfall tax debate|journal=The Guardian|first=Larry|last=Elliott|date=31 July 2008|accessdate=31 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/campaigners-call-for-windfall-tax-on-north-sea-oil-firms-421302.html|title=Campaigners call for windfall tax on North Sea oil firms|work=The Independent|location=London|first=Philip|last=Thornton|date=23 October 2006|accessdate=31 July 2008}}</ref> 120 Labour [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|MPs]] supported the call,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7600899.stm|title=Pressure for windfall tax mounts|work=BBC News|date=6 September 2008|accessdate=6 September 2008}}</ref> as well as columnist for ''[[The Guardian]]'' [[Polly Toynbee]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/jul/26/gordonbrown.glasgoweast1|title=Cardiac arrest in Glasgow - and still the clunking mantra|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Polly|last=Toynbee|date=26 July 2008|accessdate=31 July 2008}}</ref> and the left-wing pressure group [[Compass (think tank)|Compass]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/aug/27/energy.oilandgascompanies1?guni=Article:in%20body%20link|title=Good for the country, good for Labour|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Zoe|last=Cannon|date=27 August 2008|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref> There were conflicting reports in the media over whether the government was looking into implementing the tax, with suggestions that government ministers were both interested in and opposed to the idea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7536814.stm|title=Ministers 'consider' windfall tax|work=BBC News|date=1 August 2008|accessdate=1 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/windfall-tax-wont-avert-fuel-crisis-says-minister-6928082.html|title=Windfall tax won't avert fuel crisis says minister|work=London Evening Standard|first=Paul|last=Waugh|date=28 August 2008|accessdate=4 September 2008}}</ref> Despite the [[BBC]] later reporting in early September that such a windfall tax was "still an option",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7595960.stm|title=Windfall tax is 'still an option'|work=BBC News|date=3 September 2008|accessdate=4 September 2008}}</ref> then [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] confirmed at the Labour Party conference later that month that the idea had been scrapped.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/labour/3058774/Labour-Conference-Unions-flex-muscles-over-tax-and-workers-hours.html|title=Labour Conference: Unions flex muscles over tax and workers' hours |work=The Telegraph|location=London|first=James|last=Kirkup|date=22 September 2008|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref>
The issue was raised again in 2013, led by former Prime Minister [[John Major|Sir John Major]], who described the recent energy price rises of more than 10% "unacceptable", calling for a one-off emergency tax.<ref>{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24621391|title=Sir John Major calls for windfall tax on energy profits|journal=BBC News|date=22 October 2013|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref>
